title: What do you want in a fangame?
content:
Ever since Modding started, everyone's been making levels, making graphics mods, and making patches for the original games.

It seems that fangames are only made infrequently and often dropped before any serious production has begun.


So my question is this: If someone were to make a fangame, what would you want out of

For example (These are a few out of many possibilities):

A. Good sprite graphics
B. Good storyline
C. Has to be programmed effectively, and no CK2000-style bugginess.
D. Has to have excellent scenery.
E. Must have good music and sound effects
F. Creativity with the Keen universe

etc.. etc.


What would you guys want out of a fangame to make it worth downloading and making it worth that person's time creating?~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

title: ooh
content:
Most importantly, some interesting AI. One of the reasons I've enjoyed Keen1-3 considerably more than 4-6 is because the Vorticons are such diverse, flexible enemies. They jump, they follow, they're somewhat unpredictable. Vorticon Elites are quicker and can shoot, and Vortininjas are downright terrifying. There's really nothing in the later Keen games that's as dynamic and responsive.

Many of the fangames I've seen involve enemies moving along tracked paths, not even reacting to a player's presence. That works great for robots (like the good old ButlerBot)... but if the fangame's got a Bloog in it, I want it to behave at least as well as a Bloog did in Keen6. That is to say, it should change direction periodically, it should react to Keen's general presence, attempt to move towards him when possible, etc.

One of the things I loathe more than anything in fangames is the "enemy which can fire directly at you, at absurd angles which the player cannot replicate, who fires without changing their animation or giving any anticipatory warning that they are about to create a fast-moving projectile." Seriously. It's like a staple of a fangame... there has to be some enemy walking back and forth along a platform out of the player's reach, who, inexplicably, can create a bullet that travels across the entire game window in under 1 second, in a straight line towards the player, with no warning or mercy. And then, since the fangame always respawns the player immediately, and the start point is typically in an extremely inconvenient location, the player will be blasted at least twice more before they realize what's going on.

Please do not have those enemies in your game.

Part of the good AI should involve changed animations or visual cues to inform the player about what the enemy is trying to do... try to make enemies who are useful in a variety of situations, like Vorticons, rather than enemies who are limited in their scope and danger, the way Poison Slugs and Flects are.

Interesting level design can make the encounters with the enemies seem much more vivid, rather than the other way around. You can have great levels with great enemies as a foundation.

title: Re: ooh
content:
Well the great thing about mods is that they already have the Keenish controls, physics and AI, as well as a familiar and standard interface. No (complete) fangame so far has managed all of these things.

The graphics are also a key ingredient. Because they tend to be of a higher resolution than the originals, it takes a lot more effort to create decent art. It's difficult to specify an exact recipe, but you know Keenish graphics when you see them.

Ultimately, Keenishness is what is needed. Unfortunately, there is no specific formula--it's just down to experimentation.

title: Hmm...
content:
I think a good part of what defines Keen from a level-design perspective is its sense of simplicity. Levels are defined for what they are, and that's all that they are.

Each of the Guard Posts in Keen6 is designed as what is (mostly) a guard post. It doesn't look like a cityscape, it doesn't look like a cave... it's very plain and well-defined. I think that the levels which forget this (i.e. Bloogville, which doesn't really define itself as multiple buildings very well, to me) are easily forgotten. When you think of Keen, (focussing on 6 for the purpose of this train of thought,) you recall specific locations and instances--the first taste of over-industrialized complexity in Bloogfoods; the horrific climb to the very top of Bloogton Tower; the depths of the Bloogdome; the bizarre ethereal cityscape on the satelite-based Bloog Management District.

On a more specific note, the way the levels are put together contributes to this--there aren't many sharply-angled platforms in the caves... there aren't many subtle curves in the buildings... open areas tend to have arcs of points, while buildings have points lining the ceiling. Elevator and transport placement is crucial in defining how 'civilized' or 'remote' a location feels. Everything needs a purpose--even if the purpose is just to look cool or distract the player.

Hi-res sprites need more frames of animation to be convincing... It's always bothered me to see a game that runs at 800x600 but still tries to maintain a 4 frame run, or a static 'fall' animation. If you're going to make the sprites large enough that we could realistically see the clothing ripple from air resistance as the character falls, ANIMATE IT!

Personal gripe, I guess.

I think it would be wise to use a whole host of lesser known Keen songs and original cartoonish graphics. I think Xky gave what I was looking for the most:

Level design: It has to be simple, and yet effective/beautiful.

AI: The enemies have to be HARD. They have to have their own minds, basically.

Music: Has to be jazz-ish, up-beat, or techno-style dark feel.

Sounds: Have to be 'keenish'. In that they are retro-sounds and not some stupid "Hey look, that sounds exactly like fire!" type sounds, but more of a computerized

Creative canon-ness. It has to be canon. But it has to gain that "canon-ness" through creative, albiet corny, storylines and graphics. It has to feel genuine.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

title: well...
content:
Game titles don't matter so much with fangames and mods--so long as it's got "Keen" in the title, it's pretty clear it's a derivative work, based on the official titles.

I was referring more to the names of enemies. In a mod, since you're taking the behaviors for, say, a Yorp, but changing the graphics, it's important that this Yorp replacement have a name that is just as easy to remember, or memorable in some other way, so that players commenting on the mod don't simply say "Your Yorp replacement looks great!" or "The new Yorp guys were so cute!" ...

Case in point, if you name your Yorp replacement the "Garaboxifribbidibbilaramongulpollydoid," nobody is going to remember it, or they're going to butcher it horribly. "Your Garabears are adorable!" and so on.

With a custom-built fangame, this isn't nearly so much of an issue, because chances are you're not going to have an enemy with a 2 frame left/right walk who hops occasionally, and pauses to look around with a 4 frame idle.

Edit: I just wanted to type Gara-box-uh-fribbuh-dibbuh-larra-mongul-polly-doid again. It's fun to say out loud, too.
